paragraphs.zh-tw: I'd like to talk todayabout the two biggest social trends in the coming century, and perhaps in the next 10,000 years. But I want to startwith my work on romantic love, because that's my most recent work.
paragraphs.en: 今天要談的是兩大社會趨勢，在未來的一百年， 甚至是未來的一萬年。 但我想從我對愛情的研究工作開始談起， 因為那是我最近的研究結果。

paragraphs.zh-tw: What I and my colleagues did was put32 people, who were madly in love, into a functional MRI brain scanner. 17 who were madly in loveand their love was accepted; and 15 who were madly in loveand they had just been dumped.
paragraphs.en: 我和同事們把32位瘋狂陷入愛河的人們 放在MRI機器台上做了腦部掃描。 其中17位愛的瘋狂，愛有得到回應， 另15位愛得入骨，但被甩了。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And so I want to tell youabout that first, and then go on into whereI think love is going. "What 'tis to love?" Shakespeare said.
paragraphs.en: 所以我們先談談那個， 然後再說未來愛的趨勢如何。 「情為何物?」莎士比亞曾經問道。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I think our ancestors -- I think human beings have beenwondering about this question since they sat around their campfires or lay and watchedthe stars a million years ago. I started out by trying to figure outwhat romantic love was by looking at the last 45 yearsof the psychological research and as it turns out, there's a very specific group of thingsthat happen when you fall in love.
paragraphs.en: 我想,我們人類的祖先從很久以前就開始思索這個問題， 他們在夜空下圍著營火，躺下仰望繁星，百萬年前就開始沉思這個問題。 我的工作由研究愛情的本質為何開始， 我是從過去45年來的研究文獻著手--心理學範圍， 結果發現，特定的一些事情會集中發生在愛意萌生時。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The first thing that happens is, a person begins to take onwhat I call, "special meaning." As a truck driver once said to me, "The world had a new center,and that center was Mary Anne." George Bernard Shaw said it differently. "Love consists of overestimatingthe differences between one woman and another." And indeed, that's what we do.
paragraphs.en: 第一件事，墜入愛河的人， 所有事物對他而言都有了「特殊意義」 一位卡車司機跟我說， 他說：「這世界有了一個新的中心,我的瑪莉安,就是一切的中心。」 蕭伯納說的差不多， 他說：「愛的成分不過就是,在兩個女人中過度高估了其中一位」 確實如此，一點也沒錯。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And then you just focus on this person. You can list what youdon't like about them, but then you sweep that asideand focus on what you do.
paragraphs.en: 然後你就這樣專心一意在一個人身上， 你可以列出你不喜歡他們的那些事情， 但你會把不喜歡清單扔到腦後，單只看喜歡的部份。

paragraphs.zh-tw: As Chaucer said, "Love is blind." In trying to understand romantic love, I decided I would read poetryfrom all over the world, and I just want to giveyou one very short poem from eighth-century China, because it's an almost perfect example of a man who is focused totallyon a particular woman. It's a little bit like when you aremadly in love with somebody and you walk into a parking lot -- their car is differentfrom every other car in the parking lot.
paragraphs.en: 喬叟說過：「愛是盲目的」 當我嘗試著要釐清浪漫愛情， 我想就先從拜讀全世界的情詩開始吧。 我介紹一首中國第八世紀的短詩， 因為它正是表達了男人對某位特定女人如何癡迷的完美案例。 它形容十分貼切-當你瘋狂的愛上某人的時候， 當你走入停車場， 就連你愛的對象的車，都和別的車子長得不一樣，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Their wine glass at dinner is different from every other wine glassat the dinner party. And in this case, a man got hookedon a bamboo sleeping mat.
paragraphs.en: 晚宴上他們所持的酒杯，也和別的玻璃杯都不一樣。 這位男子藉一張竹席而大發相思之情 (註:「鶯鶯傳」中的張生)

paragraphs.zh-tw: And it goes like this. It's by a guy called Yuan Zhen.
paragraphs.en: 詩中這麼說，這是元稹的作品：

paragraphs.zh-tw: "I cannot bear to put awaythe bamboo sleeping mat. The night I brought you home,I watched you roll it out." He became hooked on a sleeping mat, probably because of elevated activityof dopamine in his brain, just like with you and me.
paragraphs.en: 「竹簟襯重茵，未忍都令捲。 憶昨初來日，看君自施展。」 睹物思人，對一張竹蓆難以忘情， 原因可能是大腦釋放旺盛的多巴胺， 就像你我的大腦也是如此運作。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But anyway, not only does this persontake on special meaning, you focus your attention on them. You aggrandize them.
paragraphs.en: 但不只是特殊意義的產生而已， 你的注意力集中在他們身上， 你還會誇張擴大你的對象，並且你精力無限，

paragraphs.zh-tw: But you have intense energy. As one Polynesian said,"I felt like jumping in the sky." You're up all night.You're walking till dawn.
paragraphs.en: 就像一個玻里尼亞人曾說：「我想要一躍騰空。」 你可以整夜無眠，漫步到天明。

paragraphs.zh-tw: You feel intense elationwhen things are going well; mood swings into horrible despairwhen things are going poorly. Real dependence on this person.
paragraphs.en: 一切順利如意時，你會比平常還要開心， 進展不順，心情盪到谷底， 你的情緒完完全全隨之起伏。

paragraphs.zh-tw: As one businessman in New York said to me, "Anything she liked, I liked." Simple. Romantic love is very simple. You become extremely sexually possessive.
paragraphs.en: 就像一位紐約商人所說：「只要是她喜歡的東西，我都喜歡。」 很簡單，愛情就是這麼簡單。 你在性方面極端地具有獨佔慾。

paragraphs.zh-tw: You know, if you're just sleepingwith somebody casually, you don't really careif they're sleeping with somebody else. But the moment you fall in love, you become extremelysexually possessive of them.
paragraphs.en: 如果你跟某人只是床伴， 他們和別人睡的時候你不會介意。 但一旦你愛上對方， 你對他們的性佔有慾會極端強烈。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I think there's a Darwinianpurpose to this. The whole point of thisis to pull two people together strongly enough to beginto rear babies as a team.
paragraphs.en: 我想這在人類物種的演化上中是有其目的， 目的就是要把兩個人拉近，連在一起， 非常強的拉近力，好讓他們可以組成兩人團隊養育嬰孩長大。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But the main characteristicsof romantic love are craving: an intense cravingto be with a particular person, not just sexually, but emotionally. It would be nice to go to bed with them, but you want them to call youon the telephone, to invite you out, etc., to tell you that they love you.
paragraphs.en: 但浪漫愛情的主要特徵是渴求， 強烈的想要和某一特定對象長相左右的渴求，不只是性，更是於情感上的需求。 你會很想要的是—和他們上床當然甚好， 但你更想要的是他們打電話給你，約你出去之類的。 你想聽見他們說我愛你。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The other main characteristicis motivation. The motor in the brain begins to crank,and you want this person.
paragraphs.en: 情的另一個特徵是原動力， 就像腦中有一台發電機開始運轉，讓你很想要這個人。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And last but not least,it is an obsession. Before I put these peoplein the MRI machine, I would ask them all kinds of questions.
paragraphs.en: 最後但很重要的，愛情還是一種癡迷。 當我把這些人放在MRI掃描機台上之前， 我問他們各式各樣的問題，

paragraphs.zh-tw: But my most important questionwas always the same. It was: "What percentage of the dayand night do you think about this person?" And indeed, they would say, "All day. All night.
paragraphs.en: 但我最重要的問題總是同一個， 那就是：「你有多少時候，白天或晚上，會想到這個人呢？」 他們總是回答：「整日、整夜，我無法停止想念他/她。」

paragraphs.zh-tw: I can never stop thinkingabout him or her." And then, the very last question -- I would always have to workmyself up to this question, because I'm not a psychologist. I don't work with peoplein any kind of traumatic situation.
paragraphs.en: 然後,最後我會問他們的問題是 — 我總是必須花一番功夫才能問這個問題， 因為我不是心理醫師， 我並不處理什麼心理創傷經驗，

paragraphs.zh-tw: My final question was always the same. I would say,"Would you die for him or her?" And, indeed, these people would say "Yes!" as if I had asked them to pass the salt.
paragraphs.en: 但是我最後一個問題總是一樣， 我會問：「你是否願意為他/她而死?」 這些人總是回答說：「會呀！」 就像我問他能不能遞一下鹽罐子的輕鬆平常，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I was just staggered by it. So we scanned their brains, looking at a photographof their sweetheart and looking at a neutral photograph, with a distraction task in between.
paragraphs.en: 這讓我覺得十分驚訝。 進行大腦掃描時，我們給實驗者看一張愛人的照片，另外一張是尋常普通的相片， 看這些照片之間，會有一個轉移注意力用的小活動，

paragraphs.zh-tw: So we could look at the same brainwhen it was in that heightened state and when it was in a resting state. And we found activityin a lot of brain regions.
paragraphs.en: 我們可以觀察大腦在高度運作時 以及在休息狀態的一些狀況。 我們發現一些特殊活動在腦中許多不同部位發生，

paragraphs.zh-tw: In fact, one of the most importantwas a brain region that becomes activewhen you feel the rush of cocaine. And indeed, that's exactly what happens.
paragraphs.en: 事實上最重要的活動是發生在 一塊當人吸食古柯鹼而有快感時活躍的部位。 事實上，實況就是如此。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I began to realize that romantic loveis not an emotion. In fact, I had always thoughtit was a series of emotions, from very high to very low.
paragraphs.en: 我開始了解到浪漫愛情不是一種情緒。 過去我一直認為它是一系列的情緒， 從高昂到低迷。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But actually, it's a drive. It comes from the motor of the mind, the wanting part of the mind,the craving part of the mind.
paragraphs.en: 但事實上，它是一種驅動力，直接從精神上發動出來的力量， 精神上想望和渴求的部分。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The kind of part of the mind when you're reachingfor that piece of chocolate, when you want to winthat promotion at work. The motor of the brain.
paragraphs.en: 它像是 你要吃那塊巧克力的想要， 你在工作上想得到升遷的想要， 是大腦的驅動組，它是驅動的力量。

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's a drive. And in fact, I think it's more powerfulthan the sex drive.
paragraphs.en: 事實上，我認為它比性慾的驅動力更強。

paragraphs.zh-tw: You know, if you ask somebodyto go to bed with you, and they say, "No, thank you," you certainly don't kill yourselfor slip into a clinical depression. But certainly, around the world, people who are rejectedin love will kill for it.
paragraphs.en: 當你問某人要不要和你上床，他們說「不要」 顯然你不會因此而自殺或陷入憂鬱症， 但是全世界都有人，因為在愛中被拒絕，而殺戮。

paragraphs.zh-tw: People live for love. They kill for love.
paragraphs.en: 人們為愛而生，為愛而殺，為愛而死。

paragraphs.zh-tw: They die for love. They have songs, poems, novels, sculptures, paintings, myths, legends.
paragraphs.en: 人為愛譜曲、賦詩、寫小說、刻雕像、繪畫、流傳了迷思和神話，

paragraphs.zh-tw: In over 175 societies, people have left their evidenceof this powerful brain system. I have come to think it's one of the most powerfulbrain systems on Earth for both great joy and great sorrow.
paragraphs.en: 世上超過175個社會，人們以此留下了這強大腦系統運作的證據。 我認為這是地球上最強的一種力量， 它能帶來狂悲，也能帶來狂喜。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I've also come to think that it's one of threebasically different brain systems that evolved from mating and reproduction. One is the sex drive:the craving for sexual gratification.
paragraphs.en: 這讓我想到，愛情是三者其中之ㄧ， 大腦為了適應求偶和繁殖，在演化過程中發展出三個不同的腦系統。 第一是性慾驅動：追求性滿足，

paragraphs.zh-tw: W.H. Auden called itan "intolerable neural itch," and indeed, that's what it is. It keeps bothering youa little bit, like being hungry.
paragraphs.en: 詩人奧登稱之為「難忍之癢」， 真的，很貼切， 它一直不斷的騷擾你，就像饑餓感。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The second of these three brainsystems is romantic love: that elation, obsession of early love. And the third brain system is attachment: that sense of calm and securityyou can feel for a long-term partner.
paragraphs.en: 第二個腦系統是浪漫愛情， 那種在愛情一開始，得意、熱烈、呈癡迷狀態的浪漫。 大腦中第三個系統是依存感， 是相伴已久的伴侶能帶給你的那種平穩、安全感。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I think that the sex driveevolved to get you out there, looking for a whole range of partners. You can feel it when you're justdriving along in your car.
paragraphs.en: 我認為性慾是驅動你出來， 尋找各式各樣可能的對象。 就像，當你獨自一人在開車的時候，

paragraphs.zh-tw: It can be focused on nobody. I think romantic love evolvedto enable you to focus your mating energy on just one individual at a time, thereby conserving mating time and energy.
paragraphs.en: 無意中你會注意到某個陌生人。 浪漫愛情的演化是為了要讓你在擇偶所花的精力上能產生焦點， 一次只專注在一個人上面， 這樣做可以節省擇偶的時間和精力。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I think that attachment,the third brain system, evolved to enable you to toleratethis human being at least long enough to raisea child together as a team. So with that preamble, I want to go into discussingthe two most profound social trends.
paragraphs.en: 至於大腦中第三種系統：依存感， 它的演化產生是為了，讓你對某一個人類有大一點的寬容， 至少寬容的時間夠讓你們能合力把孩子撫養長大。 有了這樣的前題，我要繼續談到兩大社會趨勢，

paragraphs.zh-tw: One of the last 10,000 years and the other,certainly of the last 25 years, that are going to have an impacton these three different brain systems: lust, romantic loveand deep attachment to a partner. The first is women working,moving into the workforce.
paragraphs.en: 第一個趨勢存在已一萬年，第二個則是出現於過去這25年— 兩者將對於這三個大腦系統帶來巨大的衝擊。 這三個系統：性慾、浪漫愛情、和深切的依附感。 第一是職業婦女，進入職場，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I've looked at 130 societies through the demographic yearbooksof the United Nations. Everywhere in the world,129 out of 130 of them, women are not only movinginto the job market -- sometimes very, very slowly,but they are moving into the job market -- and they are very slowly closingthat gap between men and women in terms of economic power,health and education.
paragraphs.en: 我看過了150 —130個社會，透過聯合國所公告的人口數字年鑑， 在世界上每個角落，130當中的129個，女性不只是進入工作市場， 有時候非常非常緩慢，但她們的確正在逐步進入職場， 而且正慢慢地在經濟影響力，健康和教育程度上 追上男女之間的落差。

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's very slow. For every trend on this planet,there's a counter-trend.
paragraphs.en: 速度很慢， 地球上每出現一個潮流，也會有個反潮流。

paragraphs.zh-tw: We all know of them, but nevertheless -- the Arabs say, "The dogs may bark,but the caravan moves on." And, indeed, that caravan is moving on. Women are moving back into the job market.
paragraphs.en: 我們都知道這是必然的，儘管如此，有句古老的阿拉伯俗語： 「狗就算吠，篷車照開。」 確實，篷車是繼續前行的。 女性又再回到了工作職場中，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I say back into the job market,because this is not new. For millions of years,on the grasslands of Africa, women commuted to workto gather their vegetables.
paragraphs.en: 而我說「再」回到了工作職場，因為這不是新鮮事。 遠古世界曾經有百萬年，在非洲大草原上， 女人以外出採集蔬果為她們的工作，

paragraphs.zh-tw: They came home with 60 to 80 percentof the evening meal. The double income family was the standard.
paragraphs.en: 帶回家供應晚餐的食物份量達60%到80%， 雙薪家庭對他們而言是常態。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And women were regardedas just as economically, socially and sexually powerful as men. In short, we're reallymoving forward to the past.
paragraphs.en: 女人在經濟、社會地位、性的方面和男人是平起平坐的。 簡言之，我們去向的前方其實是回到了古早以往。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Then, women's worstinvention was the plow. With the beginning of plow agriculture,men's roles became extremely powerful.
paragraphs.en: 之後，女人最不妙的發明就是「犁」。 有了犁田的農業，男人變重要了，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Women lost their ancientjobs as collectors, but then with the industrial revolutionand the post-industrial revolution they're moving back into the job market. In short, they are acquiring the statusthat they had a million years ago, 10,000 years ago, 100,000 years ago.
paragraphs.en: 女人則失去了他們古老的採集者的工作。 但藉由工業革命和後工業革命， 女性又再度回到了就業市場。 簡言之，她們取得的是一百萬年前、一萬年前、 或十萬年前，就已經存在的社會地位。

paragraphs.zh-tw: We are seeing now oneof the most remarkable traditions in the history of the human animal. And it's going to have an impact.
paragraphs.en: 我們現在正目擊人類歷史上最鮮明的傳統特質重現， 它會帶來一些衝擊，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I generally give a whole lecture on the impact of womenon the business community. I'll say just a couple of things,and then go on to sex and love.
paragraphs.en: 關於女性在商業社群中帶來的衝擊效應，就又是另一篇演講了， 我在此只略提一二。然後我要講的是性和愛，

paragraphs.zh-tw: There's a lot of gender differences; anybody who thinks men and women are alike simply never had a boy and a girl child. I don't know why they want to thinkthat men and women are alike.
paragraphs.en: 兩性間有很大的差異， 那些說男人和女人沒有差別的人，恐怕是自己未曾養育過一男和一女。 我不明白他們為何說男女沒什麼不同，

paragraphs.zh-tw: There's much we have in common, but there's a whole lotthat we do not have in common. We are -- in the words of Ted Hughes, "I think that we are like two feet.We need each other to get ahead." But we did not evolveto have the same brain.
paragraphs.en: 我們確實有許多共通點，但也有許多 非共通點。 套一句詩人休斯說的， 「人類生而有雙腳，雙腳彼此合作才能邁步向前 — 人類兩性也一樣，彼此需要。」 但在演化的過程中我們有了不一樣的大腦，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And we're finding more and moregender differences in the brain. I'll only just use a coupleand then move on to sex and love.
paragraphs.en: 許多的不同存在於兩性之間，就大腦而言。 我舉其中一二為例，然後接著再講性與愛。

paragraphs.zh-tw: One of them is women's verbal ability. Women can talk.
paragraphs.en: 其中之ㄧ是女性的語言能力，女人比較會說話，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Women's ability to find the right wordrapidly, basic articulation goes up in the middleof the menstrual cycle, when estrogen levels peak. But even at menstruation,they're better than the average man.
paragraphs.en: 女性能比較快找到正確的措辭，基本修辭能力， 在生理週期正中央時達到巔峰，此時雌激素最旺盛， 但即使在行經期間，她的口語表達能力也比一般男人較好，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Women can talk. They've been doing it for a million years;words were women's tools.
paragraphs.en: 女人就是會說話。 百萬年以來都如此進行，女人的工具就是言語文字。

paragraphs.zh-tw: They held that babyin front of their face, cajoling it, reprimanding it,educating it with words. And, indeed, they're becominga very powerful force.
paragraphs.en: 她們端詳雙臂中懷抱的嬰兒， 逗弄、輕聲責罵、用言語教育孩子們， 而的確，女性們正形成一股強有力的勢力，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Even in places like India and Japan, where women are not moving rapidlyinto the regular job market, they're moving into journalism. And I think that the televisionis like the global campfire.
paragraphs.en: 甚至是在印度以及日本這些地方， 女性或許沒有很快速的進入一般職場， 但她們進入了專業新聞領域， 我認為電視像是全球以之為中心的一團營火，

paragraphs.zh-tw: We sit around it and it shapes our minds. Almost always, when I'm on TV,the producer who calls me, who negotiates what we're going to say, is a woman.
paragraphs.en: 我們都環繞電視而坐，讓心智接收電視的教化。 每次當我上電視，前來和我溝通 待會要說什麼內容的製作人幾乎全是女性。

paragraphs.zh-tw: In fact, Solzhenitsyn once said, "To have a great writeris to have another government." Today 54 percent of peoplewho are writers in America are women. It's one of many, manycharacteristics that women have that they will bring into the job market.
paragraphs.en: 索忍尼辛曾說： 「好作家的功用，等同於另一個政府。」 今天有54%的美國作家是女性， 語言能力只是女性帶進工作職場 的許許多多專有特色之一。

paragraphs.zh-tw: They've got incredible people skills,negotiating skills. They're highly imaginative.
paragraphs.en: 女性還有絕佳人際溝通技巧、協商技巧 以及高度想像力。

paragraphs.zh-tw: We now know the brain circuitryof imagination, of long-term planning. They tend to be web thinkers.
paragraphs.en: 如今我們明白大腦中有想像力的線路，有長期規劃的線路。 女性是網路型思考者，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Because the female partsof the brain are better connected, they tend to collect morepieces of data when they think, put them into more complex patterns,see more options and outcomes. They tend to be contextual,holistic thinkers, what I call web thinkers.
paragraphs.en: 因為女性大腦的連結程度比較好， 思考時會收集較多的資訊， 也將資訊放進較複雜的架構中，因此看出更多的選項和後果。 她們是比較完整、能觀前顧後的思考者，我稱之為網路型思考者。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Men tend to -- and these are averages -- tend to get rid of what they regardas extraneous, focus on what they do, and move in a morestep-by-step thinking pattern. They're both perfectly goodways of thinking.
paragraphs.en: 男性則是 — 一般而言 — 捨棄他們認為多餘的， 只看他們要做的，採取一種規律步驟型的思考方式。 兩種思考方式都很好，

paragraphs.zh-tw: We need both of them to get ahead. In fact, there's many moremale geniuses in the world.
paragraphs.en: 人類同時需要這兩種思考方式才能邁步向前。 事實上，世界上男性天才是比較多的，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And there's also many moremale idiots in the world. When the male brain works well,it works extremely well.
paragraphs.en: 但是男性的笨蛋也比較多。 當男性的大腦運作良好的時候，呈現的結果非常好。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And what I really thinkthat we're doing is, we're moving towardsa collaborative society, a society in which the talentsof both men and women are becoming understoodand valued and employed. But in fact, women movinginto the job market is having a huge impacton sex and romance and family life.
paragraphs.en: 我認為，我們正朝向一個協同共工的社會演進， 在這社會中男性和女性的天賦都獲得彼此了解、 珍惜和發揮。 事實上女性進入職場帶來的一個極大衝擊 是在性、浪漫愛情及家庭生活方面。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Foremost, women are startingto express their sexuality. I'm always astonishedwhen people come to me and say, "Why is it that men are so adulterous?" "Why do you thinkmore men are adulterous than women?" "Well, men are more adulterous!" And I say, "Who do you thinkthese men are sleeping with?" And -- basic math! Anyway.
paragraphs.en: 最重要的是，女性的性自主開始覺醒。 我總是覺得驚訝當有人問我： 「為什麼男人都那麼愛出軌?」 而我總說：「你憑什麼覺得是男性比較愛出軌呢?」 「嗯，出軌的男性比較多啊!」 我說：「那你認為這些出軌男人都是和誰上床了?」 這是 — 基本算術！ 無論如何，

paragraphs.zh-tw: In the Western world, women start sooner at sex,have more partners, express less remorsefor the partners that they do, marry later, have fewer children, leave bad marriagesin order to get good ones. We are seeing the riseof female sexual expression.
paragraphs.en: 在西方世界，女孩們，嗯， 女性較早開始有性生活，也有較多的對象經驗， 分手時也較少悔恨自責。 晚婚、生育子女較少，不眷戀不幸福的婚姻，並追求幸福的婚姻， 我們正在見證女性的性自主意識抬頭，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And, indeed, once again we're movingforward to the kind of sexual expression that we probably saw on the grasslandsof Africa a million years ago, because this is the kindof sexual expression that we see in hunting and gathering societies today. We're also returningto an ancient form of marriage equality.
paragraphs.en: 再一次說，其實今日性意識表達正在演進形成的型態， 可能在百萬年以前的非洲草原上就已經存在。 因為今日現時我們所見的性表達 即是我們在狩獵和採集型社會中所見的型態。 我們也正在回溯到過去的古老平等婚姻型態。

paragraphs.zh-tw: They're now saying that the 21st century is going to be the century of whatthey call the "symmetrical marriage," or the "pure marriage,"or the "companionate marriage." This is a marriage between equals, moving forward to a pattern that is highly compatiblewith the ancient human spirit. We're also seeing a rise of romantic love.
paragraphs.en: 他們說21世紀， 將要成為所謂「對稱式婚姻」的一個世紀， 或者是「同儕式婚姻」、「伴侶型婚姻」。 這是由平等伴侶組成的婚姻， 演進為一種和古老的人類精神能相互呼應的婚姻形式。 我們也看到浪漫愛情主張的抬頭，

paragraphs.zh-tw: 91 percent of American womenand 86 percent of American men would not marry somebodywho had every single quality they were looking for in a partner, if they were not in love with that person. People around the world,in a study of 37 societies, want to be in lovewith the person that they marry.
paragraphs.en: 91%美國女性以及86%美國男性表示， 一個對象即便每一項條件和他們所開列的都符合，若不愛對方， 就不會跟對方結婚。 一個探究了37個社會的研究顯示，世界各地的人， 都希望與自己的配偶沉醉愛河。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Indeed, arranged marriages areon their way off this braid of human life. I even think that marriagesmight even become more stable because of the second great world trend.
paragraphs.en: 媒妁之言的婚姻，現已逐漸式微了， 甚至未來的婚姻我認為有希望是更穩定的， 原因是這第二項偉大的趨勢。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The first one being womenmoving into the job market, the second one beingthe aging world population. They're now saying that in America, that middle age should be regardedas up to age 85.
paragraphs.en: 第一項剛講過的，是女性進入工作職場； 第二項，是全球人口的老化趨勢。 美國現在有此一說， 中年的分界應該拉長到85歲以前算中年，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Because in that highestage category of 76 to 85, as much as 40 percent of peoplehave nothing really wrong with them. So we're seeing there's a realextension of middle age.
paragraphs.en: 因為在76到85歲這個高齡範圍中， 將近有40%的人身體上是沒有太大的毛病的， 所以我們能看到中年的定義將會擴張。

paragraphs.zh-tw: For one of my books,I looked at divorce data in 58 societies. And as it turns out, the older you get,the less likely you are to divorce.
paragraphs.en: 當為我的一本書研究找資料時，我看了58個社會的離婚統計， 結果是年紀愈大，離婚可能性愈低。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So the divorce rate right nowis stable in America, and it's actually beginning to decline. It may decline some more.
paragraphs.en: 美國離婚率現已趨於穩定， 甚至開始降低，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I would even say that with Viagra, estrogen replacement, hip replacements and the incredibly interesting women -- women have never beenas interesting as they are now. Not at any time on this planethave women been so educated, so interesting, so capable.
paragraphs.en: 有可能還會再降低更多。 我甚至認為由於威而鋼、雌激素療法、骨盆腔替換手術的普及， 以及女人們鮮明有趣的個性 — 女性在歷史上未曾有過如此的一個時代， 女性們未曾像今日這般，受良好教育、豐富內涵、能力強。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And so I honestly think that if therereally was ever a time in human evolution when we have the opportunity to makegood marriages, that time is now. However, there's always kindsof complications in this.
paragraphs.en: 因此如果要我說,人類演化史上若是 有哪個時機會創造出最好的婚姻，那就是，現在。 但是，這其中還有些複雜化的因素，

paragraphs.zh-tw: These three brain systems --lust, romantic love and attachment -- don't always go together. They can go together, by the way.
paragraphs.en: 這三個大腦系統：性慾、浪漫愛情、長期依存感， 它們並不總是一起配合作用的， 但它們確實是可以配合作用的。所以啦，

paragraphs.zh-tw: That's why casual sex isn't so casual. With orgasm you get a spike of dopamine.
paragraphs.en: 這可以解釋為什麼很多一夜情都不是一夜就結束， 因為高潮時體內多巴胺會大量產生，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Dopamine's associated with romantic love, and you can justfall in love with somebody who you're just having casual sex with. With orgasm, then you get a real rushof oxytocin and vasopressin -- those are associated with attachment.
paragraphs.en: 而多巴胺是與愛情浪漫感相關的激素， 一不小心，你就這樣和一夜情的對象墜入情網了， 在高潮來時，體內催產素和血管加壓素大量分泌， 這些激素讓人產生依賴及歸屬感，

paragraphs.zh-tw: This is why you can feel such a senseof cosmic union with somebody after you've made love to them. But these three brain systems:lust, romantic love and attachment, aren't always connected to each other.
paragraphs.en: 這就是為什麼和某人會有天人合一的感覺， 在你和對方做愛之後。 這三個大腦系統：性慾、浪漫愛情和依附感， 並不總是好好的彼此連結；

paragraphs.zh-tw: You can feel deep attachmentto a long-term partner while you feel intenseromantic love for somebody else, while you feel the sex drive for peopleunrelated to these other partners. In short, we're capable of lovingmore than one person at a time.
paragraphs.en: 你可能對長期伴侶感到深深的依附感， 同時強烈的感受對另一個人的愛戀， 然後還對這兩人以外的其他人感到性衝動。 簡言之，我們可以同時愛上好幾個人，

paragraphs.zh-tw: In fact, you can lie in bed at night and swing from deep feelingsof attachment for one person to deep feelingsof romantic love for somebody else. It's as if there's a committee meetinggoing on in your head as you are trying to decide what to do.
paragraphs.en: 事實上，當你夜晚躺在床上， 你的心思可以從一個你深深依賴歸屬的對象， 飄盪到你瘋狂癡迷的的另一個人身上。 大腦裡頭好像有個會議正在進行， 決定要怎麼辦。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So I don't think, honestly, we're an animalthat was built to be happy; we are an animalthat was built to reproduce. I think the happiness we find, we make.
paragraphs.en: 所以我不認為我們是一種為快樂而生的動物， 我們是一種為繁衍後代而生的動物。 我想我們尋找到的快樂，是我們自己創造的。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I think, however, we can make good relationshipswith each other. So I want to conclude with two things.
paragraphs.en: 而且我相信，我們有能力創造良好的伴侶關係。 所以我要用兩件事來做總結， 我要先提出一個擔憂，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I want to conclude with a worry, and with a wonderful story. The worry is about antidepressants.
paragraphs.en: 一個擔憂，搭配一個有趣的故事，做為結束。 抗憂鬱症藥品，是我所憂心的事。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Over 100 million prescriptionsof antidepressants are written every yearin the United States. And these drugs are going generic.
paragraphs.en: 美國每年開出超過一億張以上抗憂鬱症藥處方籤， 這些藥品變得垂手可得，

paragraphs.zh-tw: They are seeping around the world. I know one girl who's beenon these antidepressants, SSRIs, serotonin-enhancingantidepressants -- since she was 13.
paragraphs.en: 滲透到全世界。 我認識一位女孩子接受抗憂鬱藥治療，血清素補充療法， 從13歲開始接受SSRI，血清素補充抗憂鬱藥物治療。

paragraphs.zh-tw: She's 23. She's been on themever since she was 13. I've got nothing against peoplewho take them short term, when they're goingthrough something horrible.
paragraphs.en: 現在她23歲。她從13歲開始服用這些藥物。 對於短期服用我沒有什麼意見， 當人正經歷一些非常糟糕的時期時，

paragraphs.zh-tw: They want to commit suicideor kill somebody else. I would recommend it.
paragraphs.en: 甚至想要自殺或殺人的時候， 我建議他們吃藥。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But more and more peoplein the United States are taking them long term. And indeed, what these drugs dois raise levels of serotonin.
paragraphs.en: 但愈來愈多的美國人是長期服用， 實際上，這些藥物是用來提升血清素，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And by raising levels of serotonin,you suppress the dopamine circuit. Everybody knows that.
paragraphs.en: 血清素提高，就抑制了多巴胺的活動。 很多人都知道，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Dopamine is associated with romantic love. Not only do they suppressthe dopamine circuit, but they kill the sex drive.
paragraphs.en: 多巴胺和浪漫愛情是緊密相關的， 這些藥物不僅只是抑制了多巴胺，也滅除了性慾動力，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And when you kill the sex drive,you kill orgasm. And when you kill orgasm, you kill that flood of drugsassociated with attachment.
paragraphs.en: 沒有性慾動力，也就不會有性高潮， 沒有性高潮，那隨之而來大量使人有依附感的的化學物質也隨之消失。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The things are connected in the brain. And when you tamper with one brain system, you're going to tamper with another.
paragraphs.en: 這些物質運作在腦內是互相關聯的， 當你破壞其中一種運作的機制， 其他的也被連帶破壞了。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I'm just simply saying that a worldwithout love is a deadly place. So now -- Thank you.
paragraphs.en: 我要說的就是，這世界若沒有了愛，將是一片死寂之地。 所以...  謝謝。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I want to end with a story. And then, just a comment.
paragraphs.en: 接下來我要講一個故事，然後，加一點小注釋。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I've been studying romantic loveand sex and attachment for 30 years. I'm an identical twin;I am interested in why we're all alike.
paragraphs.en: 我研究浪漫愛情和性慾和依附感這主題有30年了， 我自己是同卵雙胞胎；我對人之間的相似性特別有興趣，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Why you and I are alike,why the Iraqis and the Japanese and the Australian Aboriginesand the people of the Amazon River are all alike. And about a year ago, an Internet dating service,Match.com, came to me and asked me if I would designa new dating site for them.
paragraphs.en: 為何你我相像，為何伊拉克人、日本人、 澳洲原住民和亞馬遜河居民，我們全都很相像？ 大約一年前，一家網路約會網站公司 Match.com 找到我， 問我能否為他們設計一個網路交友配對網站。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I said, "I don't know anythingabout personality. You know? I don't know. Do you thinkyou've got the right person?" They said, "Yes." It got me thinkingabout why it is that you fall in love with one person rather than another. That's my current project;it will be my next book.
paragraphs.en: 我說：「我對個性這回事一無所知， 我不確定，你們真的找對人了嗎?」 他們肯定，「對的」 這讓我深思，為什麼你愛了這個人不去愛那個人， 這是我現在的研究計畫，會是我下一本書的內容。

paragraphs.zh-tw: There's all kinds of reasons that you fall in lovewith one person rather than another. Timing is important.Proximity is important.
paragraphs.en: 為什麼你愛了這人不去愛那個人，原因有許多， 時機很重要、近水樓台很重要、

paragraphs.zh-tw: Mystery is important. You fall in love with somebodywho's somewhat mysterious, in part because mysteryelevates dopamine in the brain, probably pushes youover that threshold to fall in love.
paragraphs.en: 神秘感很重要，當你愛上某個有點神秘感的人， 一部分原因是神秘感會刺激大腦產生更多多巴胺， 可能就推動你跨過愛情萌芽的一個門檻。

paragraphs.zh-tw: You fall in love with somebody who fits withinwhat I call your "love map," an unconscious list of traits that you build in childhoodas you grow up. And I also thinkthat you gravitate to certain people, actually, with somewhatcomplementary brain systems.
paragraphs.en: 你會愛上一個在你的「愛情圖譜」中條件符合的人， 這圖譜上放的條件是你從小到大無意識間慢慢建立起來的一張特徵清單。 並且我認為，你會受 特定的人所吸引，事實上，是因對方大腦系統正好和你是互補型的，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And that's what I'm nowcontributing to this. But I want to tell youa story, to illustrate.
paragraphs.en: 那就是我現在正在研究的方向。 現在我要說一個故事，

paragraphs.zh-tw: I've been carrying on hereabout the biology of love. I wanted to show you a little bitabout the culture of it, too, the magic of it.
paragraphs.en: 目前為止，我一直講到愛的生物學， 我也想表達一點「愛的文化學」— 愛的神奇。

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's a story that was told to me by somebody who hadheard it just from one -- probably a true story. It was a graduate student --I'm at Rutgers and my two colleagues -- Art Aron is at SUNY Stony Brook.
paragraphs.en: 這是個我輾轉聽到的故事， 可能是真人實事， 有一位研究生—我在Rutgers執教，而我兩位同事— Art Aaron 是在 SUNY Stonybrook，

paragraphs.zh-tw: That's where we put our peoplein the MRI machine. And this graduate student was madlyin love with another graduate student, and she was not in love with him.
paragraphs.en: 那是我們進行MRI掃描機台測驗的地方。 這位研究生瘋狂的愛上另一位研究生， 但是她不愛他。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And they wereall at a conference in Beijing. And he knew from our work that if you go and do somethingvery novel with somebody, you can drive upthe dopamine in the brain, and perhaps triggerthis brain system for romantic love.
paragraphs.en: 有一次他們一起去北京參加會議， 這位研究生從我們所做的研究中知道，如果你和某人去玩些新奇的事物， 大腦中的多巴胺會增多， 有機會觸動大腦點起浪漫愛情之火。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So he decided he'd put science to work. And he invited this girl to go offon a rickshaw ride with him.
paragraphs.en: 所以他決定動手實作， 邀請這位女孩和他來一趟黃包車之旅。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And sure enough -- I've never been in one, but apparently they goall around the buses and the trucks and it's crazy and it's noisyand it's exciting. He figured that thiswould drive up the dopamine, and she'd fall in love with him.
paragraphs.en: 當然，我沒坐過黃包車， 但顯然他們沿途要閃過許多巴士、卡車， 很驚險很吵很興奮。 他想這必定能讓多巴胺增多， 然後，她就會愛上他了。

paragraphs.zh-tw: So off they go and she's squealingand squeezing him and laughing and having a wonderful time. An hour later they get downoff of the rickshaw, and she throws her hands up and she says, "Wasn't that wonderful?" And, "Wasn't that rickshawdriver handsome!" There's magic to love! But I will end by sayingthat millions of years ago, we evolved three basic drives: the sex drive, romantic love and attachment to a long-term partner.
paragraphs.en: 於是他們上了路，她時而尖叫，時而緊摟他， 笑聲不斷的共度非常好的一段時光。 一小時候他們從黃包車上下來了， 女孩子高舉雙手興奮的說，「搭黃包車真是好玩!」 「你看你看，那個拉黃包車的司機，真的是，多帥啊!」 愛的魔力！ 百萬年前開始，我們演化了三種基本的需求動力， 性慾動力、浪漫愛情動力、以及和長期伴侶互相依存，

paragraphs.zh-tw: These circuits are deeplyembedded in the human brain. They're going to surviveas long as our species survives on what Shakespeare called"this mortal coil." Thank you.
paragraphs.en: 這些迴路深植在人體大腦中， 人類存活多久，這些迴路也將存活多久， 存活在這莎士比亞說「終究將歸於死亡的皮囊」中。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Chris Anderson: Helen Fisher!
paragraphs.en: 謝謝大家。

title: Helen Fisher Tells Us Why We Love Cheat
